Title: Care About Your Craft
Description: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

Title: Think! About Your Work
Description: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work

Title: You Have Agency
Description: It's your life. Grab hold of it and make it what you want

Title: Provide Options, Don't Make Lame Excuses
Description: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don't say it can't be done; explain what can be done

Title: Don't Live with Broken Windows
Description: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them

Title: Be a Catalyst for Change
Description: You can't force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it

Title: Remember the Big Picture
Description: Don't get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what's happening around you

Title: Make Quality a Requirements Issue
Description: Involve your users in determining the project's real quality requirements

Title: Invest Regularly in Your Knowledge Portfolio
Description: Make learning a habit

Title: Critically Analyze What You Read and Hear
Description: Don't be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project

Title: English is Just Another Programming Language
Description: Treat English as Just Another Programming Language. Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, ETC, automation, and so on

Title: It's Both What You Say and the Way You Say It
Description: There's no point in having great ideas if you don't communicate them effectively

Title: Build Documentation In, Don't Bolt It On
Description: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date

Title: Good Design Is Easier to Change Than Bad Design
Description: A thing is well designed if it adapts to the people who use it. For code, that means it must adapt by changing

Title: DRY-Don't Repeat Yourself
Description: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system

Title: Make It Easy to Reuse
Description: If it's easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse

Title: Eliminate Effects Between Unrelated Things
Description: Design components that are self-contained, independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose

Title: There Are No Final Decisions
Description: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change

Title: Forgo Following Fads
Description: Neal Ford says, "Yesterday's Best Practice Becomes Tomorrow's Antipattern." Choose architectures based on fundamentals, not fashion

Title: Use Tracer Bullets to Find the Target
Description: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land

Title: Prototype to Learn
Description: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn

Title: Program Close to the Problem Domain
Description: Design and code in the language of the problem domain

Title: Estimate to Avoid Surprises
Description: Estimate before you start. You'll spot potential problems up front

Title: Iterate the Schedule with the Code
Description: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales

Title: Keep Knowledge in Plain Text
Description: Plain text won't become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing

Title: Use the Power of Command Shells
Description: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don't cut it

Title: Achieve Editor Fluency
Description: An editor is your most important tool. Know how to make it do what you need, quickly and accurately

Title: Always Use Version Control
Description: Version control is a time machine for your work; you can go back

Title: Fix the Problem, Not the Blame
Description: It doesn't really matter whether the bug is your fault or someone else's-it is still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed

Title: Don't Panic
Description: This is true for galactic hitchhikers and for developers

Title: Failing Test Before Fixing Code
Description: Create a focussed test that reveals the bug before you try fixing it

Title: Read the Damn Error Message
Description: Most exceptions tell both what failed and where it failed. If you're lucky you might even get parameter values

Title: "select" Isn't Broken
Description: It is rare to find a bug in the OS or the compiler, or even a third-party product or library. The bug is most likely in the application

Title: Don't Assume It-Prove It
Description: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment-with real data and boundary conditions

Title: Learn a Text Manipulation Language
Description: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you?

Title: You Can't Write Perfect Software
Description: Software can't be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors

Title: Design with Contracts
Description: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do

Title: Crash Early
Description: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one

Title: Use Assertions to Prevent the Impossible
Description: If it can't happen, use assertions to ensure that it won't. Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an uncertain world

Title: Finish What You Start
Description: Where possible, the function or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it

Title: Act Locally
Description: Keep the scope of mutable variables and open resources short and easily visible

Title: Take Small Steps-Always
Description: Small steps always; check the feedback; and adjust before proceeding

Title: Avoid Fortune-Telling
Description: Only look ahead as far as you can see

Title: Decoupled Code Is Easier to Change
Description: Coupling ties things together, so that it's harder to change just one thing

Title: Tell, Don't Ask
Description: Don't get values from an object, transform them, and then stick them back. Make the object do the work

Title: Don't Chain Method Calls
Description: Try not to have more than one dot when you access something

Title: Avoid Global Data
Description: It's like adding an extra parameter to every method

Title: If It's Important Enough To Be Global, Wrap It in an API
Description: .but only if you really, really want it to be global

Title: Programming Is About Code, But Programs Are About Data
Description: All programs transform data, converting an input into an output. Start designing using transformations

Title: Don't Hoard State; Pass It Around
Description: Don't hang on to data within a function or module. Take one down and pass it around

Title: Don't Pay Inheritance Tax
Description: Consider alternatives that better fit your needs, such as interfaces, delegation, or mixins

Title: Prefer Interfaces to Express Polymorphism
Description: Interfaces make polymorphism explicit without the coupling introduced by inheritance

Title: Delegate to Services: Has-A Trumps Is-A
Description: Don't inherit from services: contain them

Title: Use Mixins to Share Functionality
Description: Mixins add functionality to classes without the inheritance tax. Combine with interfaces for painless polymorphism

Title: Parameterize Your App Using External Configuration
Description: When code relies on values that may change after the application has gone live, keep those values external to the app. When you application will run in different environments, and potentially for different customers, keep the environment and customer specific values outside the app

Title: Analyze Workflow to Improve Concurrency
Description: Exploit concurrency in your user's workflow

Title: Shared State Is Incorrect State
Description: Shared state opens a large can of worms that can often only be fixed by rebooting

Title: Random Failures Are Often Concurrency Issues
Description: Variations in timing and context can expose concurrency bugs, but in inconsistent and irreproducible ways

Title: Use Actors For Concurrency Without Shared State
Description: Use Actors to manage concurrent state without explicit synchronization

Title: Use Blackboards to Coordinate Workflow
Description: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants

Title: Listen to Your Inner Lizard
Description: When it feels like your code is pushing back, it's really your subconscious trying to tell you something's wrong

Title: Don't Program by Coincidence
Description: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don't confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan

Title: Estimate the Order of Your Algorithms
Description: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code

Title: Test Your Estimates
Description: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn't tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment

Title: Refactor Early, Refactor Often
Description: Just as you might weed and rearrange a garden, rewrite, rework, and re-architect code when it needs it. Fix the root of the problem

Title: Testing Is Not About Finding Bugs
Description: A test is a perspective into your code, and gives you feedback about its design, api, and coupling

Title: A Test Is the First User of Your Code
Description: Use its feedback to guide what you do

Title: Build End-To-End, Not Top-Down or Bottom Up
Description: Build small pieces of end-to-end functionality, learning about the problem as you go

Title: Design to Test
Description: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code

Title: Test Your Software, or Your Users Will
Description: Test ruthlessly. Don't make your users find bugs for you

Title: Use Property-Based Tests to Validate Your Assumptions
Description: Property-based tests will try things you never thought to try, and exercise your code in ways is wasn't meant to be used

Title: Keep It Simple and Minimize Attack Surfaces
Description: Complex code creates a breeding ground for bugs and opportunities for attackers to exploit

Title: Apply Security Patches Quickly
Description: Attackers deploy exploits as quick as they can, you have to be quicker

Title: Name Well; Rename When Needed
Description: Name to express your intent to readers, and rename as soon as that intent shifts

Title: No One Knows Exactly What They Want
Description: They might know a general direction, but they won't know the twists and turns

Title: Programmers Help People Understand What They Want
Description: Software development is an act of co-creation between users and programmers

Title: Requirements Are Learned in a Feedback Loop
Description: Understanding requirements requires exploration and feedback, so the consequences of decisions can be used to refine the initial ideas

Title: Work with a User to Think Like a User
Description: It's the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used

Title: Policy Is Metadata
Description: Don't hardcode policy into a system; instead express it as metadata used by the system

Title: Use a Project Glossary
Description: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project

Title: Don't Think Outside the Box-Find the Box
Description: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: "Does it have to be done this way? Does it have to be done at all?"

Title: Don't Go into the Code Alone
Description: Programming can be difficult and demanding. Take a friend with you

Title: Agile Is Not a Noun; Agile Is How You Do Things
Description: Agile is an adjective: it's how you do something

Title: Maintain Small Stable Teams
Description: Teams should be small and stable, where everyone trusts each other and depends on each other

Title: Schedule It to Make It Happen
Description: If you don't schedule it, it's not going to happen. Schedule reflection, experimentation, learning and skills improvement

Title: Organize Fully Functional Teams
Description: Organize Around Functionality, Not Job Functions. Don't separate UI/UX designers from coders, frontend from backend, testers from data modelers, design from deployment. Build teams so you can build code end-to-end, incrementally and iteratively

Title: Do What Works, Not What's Fashionable
Description: Don't adopt a development method or technique just because other companies are doing it. Adopt what works for your team, in your context

Title: Deliver When Users Need It
Description: Don't wait weeks or months to deliver just because your process demands it

Title: Use Version Control to Drive Builds, Tests, and Releases
Description: Use commits or pushes to trigger builds, tests, releases. Use a version control tag to deploy to production

Title: Test Early, Test Often, Test Automatically
Description: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf

Title: Coding Ain't Done 'Til All the Tests Run
Description: 'Nuff said

Title: Use Saboteurs to Test Your Testing
Description: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them

Title: Test State Coverage, Not Code Coverage
Description: Identify and test significant program states. Testing just lines of code isn't enough

Title: Find Bugs Once
Description: Once a human tester finds a bug, it should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic tests should check for it from then on

Title: Don't Use Manual Procedures
Description: A computer will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time

Title: Delight Users, Don't Just Deliver Code
Description: Develop solutions that produce business value for your users and delight them every day

Title: Sign Your Work
Description: Artisans of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too

Title: First, Do No Harm
Description: Failure is inevitable. Make sure no one will suffer because of it

Title: Don't Enable Scumbags
Description: Because you risk becoming one, too

Title: It's Your Life. Share it. Celebrate it. Build it. AND HAVE FUN!
Description: Enjoy this amazing life we have, and do great things
